hook.text: An email goes company-wide asking for help with a crisis. Fifty people read it. Nobody responds. Everyone waited.

buildup.text: The bystander effect: the more people present, the less likely anyone acts. Responsibility diffuses across the group.

discovery.text: Darley and LatanÃ© proved it: people alone helped 85% of the time. In groups of five, only 31% did. Numbers paralyze.

twist.text: Leaders trigger the bystander effect by sending requests to 'everyone.' When everyone is responsible, nobody is.

climax.text: Name a person. 'Sarah, I need you on this.' Direct assignment breaks the spell. Specificity creates ownership.

punchline.text: Don't ask the room. Ask someone in it.

quiz.question: What is the bystander effect?
options: More witnesses means less individual action
